questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography 

 

Dobutamine stress echocardiography (DSE) evaluates myocardial ischemia and contractile reserve under pharmacologic stress. It provides both diagnostic and prognostic information, helping to stratify the risk of perioperative cardiac events in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery. DSE is especially useful in patients who cannot perform exercise testing due to limited mobility or comorbidities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exercise ECG testing: Useful for detecting ischemia in patients able to perform exercise, but limited sensitivity and specificity, and less accurate in predicting perioperative outcomes.

 

Option C. Myocardial perfusion scintigraphy: Provides perfusion imaging and risk assessment, but is more expensive, less readily available, and may overestimate risk in certain populations.

 

Option D. Coronary angiography: Gold standard for anatomic coronary assessment, but it is invasive, not routinely performed purely for preoperative risk stratification, and does not provide functional information about perioperative risk.

questions.text: Identify A, B and C
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-HR, B- O2 saturation, C-ETCO2 

 

The image shows monitor readings commonly used during anesthesia or critical care for continuous patient monitoring

 

The correct identification of the monitor readings is:

A: Heart Rate (HR)
B: Oxygen Saturation (SpO2)
C: End-tidal CO2 (ETCO2)

 

 

Thus,

 

HR (A) is shown as 77 (green, with ECG waves).

 

SpO2 (B) is 97 (cyan, with pleth waveform).

 

ETCO2 (C) is 7 (purple, with capnogram waveform).

 

The number shown at bottom as 99/59 is Blood Pressure of Patient and (67) is Pulse Rate.

 

The monitor also has ALARMS to indicate for critical values which notifies via a beeping sound whenever the values turn critical.

choices.text: Administer top up NM blocking agent
Ask surgeon to limit blood loss

questions.text: You are a very smart intern and the anaesthetist on duty trusts you with monitoring a patient after induction while he goes to the next case and asks you to give any medications if needed. You keep observing the monitor continuously and is shown in the image below. What is the next step in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer top up NM bloking agent

 

The image shows multiple Troughs in the yellow waveform, i.e.,. Curare clefts on the capnography, which indicate partial return of spontaneous respiratory efforts during mechanical ventilation.

 

This occurs when the effect of the neuromuscular blocking (NMB) agent is wearing off.

 

The appropriate response is to administer a top-up dose of NMB agent to maintain adequate muscle relaxation for surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV dantrolene sodium: Used to treat malignant hyperthermia, which presents with rapid rise in ETCO₂, hyperthermia, tachycardia, rigidity. Malignant hyperthermia shows stepladder pattern of sudden rise in ETCO2 as shown:         

 

 

Option C. Reassure yourself that “all is well”: Ignoring curare clefts could lead to inadequate muscle relaxation, patient movement, or interference with surgery.

 

Option D. Ask surgeon to limit blood loss: Not relevant to curare clefts; blood loss does not cause this capnography pattern. On capnography, this typically shows as gradual decrease in end-tidal CO₂ (ETCO2), because CO₂ delivery to the lungs falls due to reduced cardiac output.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Halfway through the surgery, a sudden drop in EtCO2 to 8 mm Hg was noted. His SpO2 became 90% and blood pressure dropped to 70/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O. What is the diagnosis?

 

  1. CO2 embolism
  2. Severe bronchospasm
  3. Pneumothorax
  4. Single bronchus intubation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 only 

 

CO₂ embolism:

 

Typical signs: Sudden drop in ETCO₂, hypotension, hypoxia, possible cardiovascular collapse.

 

Occurs during laparoscopic surgery when CO₂ is insufflated into the peritoneum and enters a venous vessel.

 

Other Options:

 

Sudden ETCO₂ drop to 8mm Hg with normal peak airway pressure (18 cm H₂O).

 

Severe bronchospasm (2): Would show increased peak airway pressure, wheezing, possible ETCO₂ retention (not sudden drop).

 

Pneumothorax (3): Usually causes increased peak airway pressure, reduced breath sounds, and ETCO₂ may drop gradually.             

 

Single bronchus intubation (4): Causes reduced ETCO₂ and desaturation, but peak airway pressures usually increase, and timing is more gradual or post-intubation.

 

Some of Common Capnography Wave Forms are given below:

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient was given celiac plexus block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a refractory abdominal pain secondary to carcinoma pancreas. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPR with 20% intralipid 

 

  • Sudden cardiovascular collapse immediately after local anesthetic injection suggests local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), most likely bupivacaine-induced cardiac arrest.
  • Mechanism: Bupivacaine blocks sodium channels in myocardium, causing arrhythmias, conduction block, and cardiovascular collapse.

 

Management:

 

1. Immediate CPR according to ACLS.

 

2. 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE / intralipid):

 

  • Acts as a “lipid sink”, binding lipophilic local anesthetic molecules and reducing myocardial toxicity.
  • Recommended dose: Initial bolus 1.5 mL/kg over 1 min, followed by infusion 0.25–0.5 mL/kg/min.

 

3. Supportive care: Vasopressors, antiarrhythmics (avoid bupivacaine-sensitive drugs like amiodarone), oxygen, and advanced monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CPR with sodium bicarbonate: Indicated in severe metabolic acidosis or tricyclic overdose, not first-line for bupivacaine cardiac arrest.

 

Option C. CPR with dobutamine: Dobutamine is a positive inotrope, helps in Cardiogenic Shock, but in bupivacaine-induced cardiac arrest, lipid therapy is the cornerstone. 

 

Option D. CPR with calcium: Calcium may support contractility but does not bind or reverse local anesthetic toxicity. Calcium helps in Cardiac protection. Not sufficient as primary therapy.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used cranial nerve for monitoring the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The setup shown in the image is used for neuromuscular monitoring in anaesthesia, which typically uses nerve stimulators to assess the degree of muscle relaxation (paralysis) during and after surgeries requiring muscle relaxants. Here the image shows Ulnar nerve monitoring using Adductor Pollicis muscle. 

 

Most commonly used cranial nerve for monitoring:

 

The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is the most commonly used cranial nerve for neuromuscular monitoring in this context, especially when monitoring the orbicularis oculi or corrugator supercilii muscles for facial nerve stimulation.

 

Facial nerve monitoring provides information about the onset and adequacy of neuromuscular blockade, which is critical for timing of intubation and ensuring proper muscle relaxation during certain surgical procedures.

questions.text: A 24-year-old young truck driver has developed a fissure in ano. What would be the ideal anesthesia for this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Saddle anesthesia

 

Saddle anesthesia is ideal for procedures involving the perineal area, such as fissure in ano, as it provides anesthesia to the areas in contact with a saddle (perineum, buttocks, inner thighs) while allowing the patient to remain awake and maintain control over their upper body. It is a targeted form of spinal anesthesia that limits the anesthetic effect to the lower pelvis and perineal region.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudal anesthesia: Caudal anesthesia, administered through the sacral hiatus, can also anesthetize the lower perineal area but is more commonly used in pediatric patients and may provide a broader block than necessary for a simple anal fissure procedure in adults.

 

Option B. Epidural anesthesia: Epidural anesthesia provides a broader area of anesthesia and may be more invasive than required for this minor procedure. It is often reserved for longer or more extensive surgeries or cases where postoperative pain control is essential.

 

Option D. Spinal anesthesia: While spinal anesthesia can be used, it often results in a more extensive block than needed for an anal fissure procedure. Saddle anesthesia specifically targets the perineal area, reducing unnecessary anesthesia to other regions.

 

Educational Objective:


Saddle anesthesia is the preferred choice for procedures involving the perineum, like fissure in ano, as it provides targeted anesthetic coverage to the relevant area without affecting the entire lower body.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be avoided for a daycare procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Morphine

 

Morphine is a long-acting opioid that can cause prolonged sedation, respiratory depression, nausea, and delayed discharge, making it unsuitable for daycare procedures. Its effects are unpredictable in ambulatory patients and may prolong recovery. Morphine’s long duration and side effects make it the least suitable drug for ambulatory settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propofol: Short-acting intravenous anaesthetic; excellent for rapid induction and quick recovery, ideal for daycare procedures.

 

Option C. Sevoflurane: Volatile anaesthetic with low blood-gas solubility, allows rapid induction and emergence; suitable for outpatient anaesthesia.

 

Option D. Sugammadex: Reversal agent for rocuronium/vecuronium; rapidly reverses neuromuscular blockade, facilitating early recovery and discharge.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery, and the anesthesia team needs to ensure the proper connection of the oxygen supply. Which of the following PIN (Pin-Index) configurations corresponds to the oxygen supply in medical gas cylinders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

The Pin-Index Safety System (PISS) is designed to prevent wrong gas cylinder connections in medical gas systems.

 

For oxygen cylinders, the correct pin-index configuration is pins 2 and 5. This unique combination ensures that only an oxygen cylinder fits on the oxygen yoke, preventing accidental cross-connection with other gases.

 

Other common configurations include:

 

Nitrous oxide: pins 3 and 5

 

Medical air: pins 1 and 5

 

Entonox: pin 7 (single pin)

 

CO2 : pins 1 and 6 if concentration of CO2 is >7% 

 

CO2 : 2 and 6 if concentration of CO2 is <7%

choices.text: Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse
Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output

questions.text: In a patient on mechanical ventilation and placed in prone position which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse 

 

Prone positioning improves ventilation-perfusion matching by redistributing lung perfusion and opening dependent alveoli. This helps prevent atelectasis and alveolar collapse, especially in patients with ARDS or those on mechanical ventilation. It promotes more uniform lung expansion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces CO₂ in alveoli: CO₂ elimination depends on minute ventilation and alveolar ventilation, not directly dependent on Prone positioning.

 

Option C. Decreases inspiratory pressure: Prone position may actually increase or maintain airway pressures; it doesn’t inherently decrease inspiratory pressure.

 

Option D. Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output: Prone position may reduce venous return due to abdominal compression and can sometimes decrease cardiac output in certain patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prone positioning is primarily used to improve oxygenation and prevent alveolar collapse, not directly for CO₂ elimination or hemodynamics.

choices.text: Defibrillate using monophasic defibrillator at 360 joules
Defibrillate using biphasic defibrillator at 360 joules

questions.text: You are the team leader during a cardiac arrest resuscitation scenario in a hospital setting. A 65-year-old patient has suddenly collapsed and is unresponsive. The monitor displays a rhythm as shown in the image. What is the next immediate step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Defibrillate using monophasic defibrillator at 360 joules

 

The rhythm in the image is ventricular fibrillation—a shockable rhythm in cardiac arrest. For monophasic defibrillators, the recommended dose is 360 joules for each shock. Thus, the next immediate step is defibrillation with a monophasic defibrillator at 360J 

 

This action provides the highest chance for successful conversion of VF to a perfusing rhythm and is in line with current ACLS guidelines

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administering epinephrine: Epinephrine is given after initial defibrillation attempts and ongoing CPR cycles if VF persists

 

Option B. Starting high-quality CPR: If a defibrillator is not immediately available, begin CPR immediately while preparing for defibrillation.

 

Option D. Defibrillate using biphasic defibrillator at 360 joules: Biphasic devices deliver lower energy (typically 120-200 J initial) with improved efficacy and less myocardial injury compared to monophasic. This is preferred when biphasic defibrillators are available over monophasic.

questions.text:
The patient, weighing 70 kg, arrived at the emergency department with acute pancreatitis and was subsequently transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and put on a ventilator with the following settings: Fraction of Inspired Oxygen (FiO2) at 90%, Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) set to 12 mmHg, respiratory rate at 16 breaths per minute, and a tidal volume of 420 ml. The results of the arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis are provided below. What would be the appropriate next course of action for managing this patient?

 

pH – 7.33

 

PaO2 – 110 mmHg

 

PaCO2 – 60 mmHg

 

spO2 – 98%
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase respiratory rate

 

  • The patient has respiratory acidosis (pH 7.33, PaCO₂ 60 mmHg), indicating hypoventilation.
  • Oxygenation is adequate (PaO₂ 110 mmHg, SpO₂ 98%), so FiO₂ and PEEP are sufficient.
  • Tidal volume is already set at ~6 ml/kg of predicted body weight, which is lung-protective for ARDS/acute pancreatitis patients. Increasing it risks barotrauma.
  • The safest and most effective way to reduce PaCO₂ is to increase the respiratory rate, which will increase minute ventilation and remove CO₂.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increase PEEP to 16: PEEP is already high at 12 mmHg; increasing it won’t improve CO₂ clearance and may reduce venous return.

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Not recommended due to risk of ventilator-induced lung injury; current volume is lung-protective.

 

Option D. Reduce FiO₂: Oxygenation is adequate, but the primary issue is hypercapnia, not oxygenation. Reducing FiO2 may cause impaired oxygenation.

questions.text: What does phase II represent in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Expiration of mixed air

 

Phase II in the given capnography image represents the expiration of mixed air—a combination of dead space air (no CO₂) and alveolar air (CO₂-rich). This phase is seen as the rapid upstroke on the capnogram, transitioning from the baseline (dead space) to the alveolar plateau as alveolar gas mixes with exhaled air.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Inspiration: The waveform phase that represents inspiration is the flat baseline segment following the downward slope after the alveolar plateau, commonly referred to as phase 0 or the inspiratory phase on a capnogram.

 

Option B. Expiration of dead space air: This actually represents phase I, where the gas exhaled is mostly from anatomic dead space with negligible to no CO₂. Phase II follows transition from dead space to alveolar air.

 

Option D. Expiration of alveolar air: This corresponds to phase III, the alveolar plateau phase, not phase II.

questions.text: While resuscitating a newborn in the labor room, after bag and mask ventilation for 1 min at room air, the infant is still pale and hypoxic. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Readjust the mask

 

  • Effective ventilation is the most critical step in newborn resuscitation. If the baby is not improving after 1 minute of bag-and-mask ventilation, the first step is to ensure proper technique, which includes mask seal, airway positioning, and head tilt.
  • Most cases of persistent hypoxia are due to ineffective ventilation rather than the need for higher oxygen or intubation.

 

MR SOPA is an acronym used in neonatal resuscitation to guide corrective steps during ineffective positive pressure ventilation (PPV) by mask. It helps healthcare providers systematically troubleshoot ventilation problems to achieve effective lung inflation. The steps are:

 

  • M: Mask adjustment — Reapply the mask with proper technique and fit.
  • R: Reposition airway — Place head in neutral or slight extension.
  • S: Suction mouth and nose — Clear secretions that may obstruct airway.
  • O: Open mouth — Open the mouth and lift jaw forward.
  • P: Pressure increase — Increase inspiratory pressure incrementally until chest rise is seen.
  • A: Alternative airway — If all else fails, insert endotracheal tube or laryngeal mask airway.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increase FiO₂ to 30%: Oxygen should be increased only after confirming effective ventilation, not before.

 

Option C. Intubate: Intubation is indicated if mask ventilation fails despite proper technique or if prolonged resuscitation is needed.

 

Option D. Start chest compressions: Chest compressions are indicated only if heart rate remains <60/min after 30 seconds of effective ventilation, not before ensuring adequate ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)

 

 

  • Mapleson Circuit Type A[Magill’s] is most effective for Spontaneous Ventilation.
  • For spontaneous breathing, the efficiency of Mapleson circuits (from most to least effective) is: A > D > C > B
  • Efficiency Order for Controlled Ventilation (from best → worst) :D > B > C > A

 

Explanation of Circuits - (Mapleson Classification):

 

  • Type A (Magill’s circuit / Mapleson A):
    • Most efficient for spontaneous breathing (least fresh gas flow required).
    • Requires only ~70 mL/kg/min fresh gas flow.
    • Commonly used in adults.
    • Lac’s circuit is Co-axial modification of Magill’s Circuit.
  • Type B & C:
    • Rarely used.
    • Less efficient both for controlled and spontaneous ventilation.
  • Type D (Bain’s circuit – coaxial modification):
    • Most efficient for controlled ventilation, but not ideal for spontaneous breathing.
  • Type E (Ayre’s T-piece):
    • Used in pediatrics, no valves, minimal dead space.
    • Inefficient in adults due to high fresh gas requirement.
  • Type F (Jackson-Rees modification of T-piece):
    • Mostly pediatric use; allows scavenging of gases.

questions.text: What is the recommended dose of adrenaline for a child during cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.01 mg/kg (1ml/kg of 1:10,000 solution)

 

  • During paediatric cardiac arrest, the recommended intravenous/intraosseous dose of adrenaline is 0.01 mg/kg, which corresponds to 1 ml/kg of a 1:10,000 solution.
  • This dose is repeated every 3–5 minutes during ongoing resuscitation.
  • The goal is to improve coronary and cerebral perfusion by causing peripheral vasoconstriction without causing excessive tachycardia or arrhythmias.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. 0.1 mg/kg (1 ml/kg of 1:1,000 solution): This is 10 times higher than recommended and is typically used for anaphylaxis, not cardiac arrest.

 

Option C. 0.001 mg/kg (1 ml/kg of 1:100,000 solution): This dose is too low for arrest; may be used for local infiltration in surgery.

 

Option D. 0.5 mg/kg (1 ml/kg of 1:2,000 solution): This is dangerously high and not used in resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following patient with X-ray as shown below is posted for immediate laparotomy. Which of the following anesthetic agent is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nitrous oxide

 

Nitrous oxide is contraindicated in this patient with bowel obstruction (as shown by the X-ray with dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels) because nitrous oxide rapidly diffuses into gas-filled spaces, leading to further bowel distension, risk of perforation, and compromised surgical field.

 

Other agents (desflurane, halothane, isoflurane) do not have this effect on bowel gas and are not contraindicated. 

 

Therefore, Nitrous oxide is absolutely contraindicated in this setting due to the risk of exacerbating bowel distension or perforation

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Volatile anesthetic, can be safely used; does not expand air-filled cavities. It has ADR of producing Pungent Odour

 

Option C. Halothane: Also safe in bowel obstruction; primarily hepatotoxic in repeated use but not acutely contraindicated.

 

Option D. Isoflurane: Safe; does not cause gas expansion and provides adequate anesthesia. It is generally used in patients undergoing surgery with Cardiovascular pathology.

questions.text: Which of the following is measured by the device shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Percentage of saturated Hb

 

The device in the image is a pulse oximeter. It measures the percentage of haemoglobin saturated with oxygen (SpO2) in the blood, providing a continuous, non-invasive indication of arterial oxygen saturation. 

 

  • A pulse oximeter non-invasively measures arterial oxygen saturation (SpO₂), which is the percentage of haemoglobin molecules bound to oxygen.
  • It uses two wavelengths of light (red and infrared) to differentiate oxygenated from deoxygenated haemoglobin and calculates the saturation by principle of photoplethysmography and the Beer-Lambert Law.
  • SpO₂ provides a quick estimate of oxygenation but does not measure PaO₂ or total oxygen content.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxygen content of the blood: Depends on both haemoglobin concentration and PaO₂; not measured directly by a pulse oximeter. Needs Hb level to be checked by Hemogram and simultaneously PaO2.

 

Option C. Partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂): Requires arterial blood gas analysis, not pulse oximetry.

 

Option D. Amount of inspired oxygen (FiO₂): Set on the ventilator or oxygen delivery device; pulse oximeter cannot measure this.

choices.text: Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness
Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine

questions.text: A 70 kg elderly athlete undergoes surgery and is administered succinylcholine due to the unavailability of vecuronium. A total of 640 mg of succinylcholine is given intermittently. During recovery, the patient is unable to breathe spontaneously or move limbs. What is the explanation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phase 2 blockade produced by succinylcholine

 

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker.
  • When high doses(2-10mg/kg) or repeated doses are given (as in this case: 640 mg), the neuromuscular junction may transition from phase 1 (depolarizing) to phase 2 (desensitizing) blockade.
  • Phase 2 blockade mimics non-depolarizing blockade: the patient becomes flaccid and cannot move or breathe, and response to reversal agents is different.
  • Unlike phase 1, neostigmine may reverse phase 2 blockade only partially or paradoxically worsen it, so careful monitoring is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudocholinesterase deficiency increasing action of succinylcholine: Causes prolonged action of normal doses of succinylcholine, but the dose here is supramaximal, making phase 2 blockade more likely.

 

Option C. Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness: Would predispose to hyperkalemia or increased sensitivity, but acute flaccid paralysis after high-dose succinylcholine points to phase 2 blockade.

 

Option D. Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine: Fasciculations are transient muscle twitches, not prolonged paralysis which would cause muscular weakness.

 

TOF and types of Blocks:

questions.text: According to the latest AHA guidelines, what is the sixth link added to the "Chain of Survival"?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery

 

  • The original “Chain of Survival” had 5 links:
    1. Early recognition and call for help (activate EMS)
    2. Early CPR
    3. Rapid defibrillation
    4. Effective advanced life support
    5. Post-cardiac arrest care
  • The latest AHA update adds a 6th link: “Recovery”, emphasizing:
    • Rehabilitation after cardiac arrest
    • Psychological support for survivors and families
    • Community reintegration to improve quality of life

 

Other Option: 

 

Option C. Early discharge: Not part of the official chain; recovery is broader, including rehab and reintegration.

questions.text: What is AMBU aura 40?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First generation supraglottic airway device

 

  • AMBU Aura 40 is a first-generation supraglottic airway device (SAD).It is named because it can be re used upto 40times.

 

 

  • First-generation SADs:
    • Provide a simple airway seal over the laryngeal inlet.
    • Do not have a gastric drainage tube.
    • Used for routine airway management in elective surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Second generation supraglottic airway device: Have gastric access, higher seal pressures, and improved safety. Examples include LMA ProSeal or AMBU AuraGain

 

Option C & D. Third generation supraglottic airway device: & Fourth generation supraglottic airway device: Feature advanced designs for higher seal, intubation compatibility, or integrated monitoring. Eg- Video Laryngeal Mask (VLMTM)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is scheduled for elective hernia repair surgery. His preoperative assessment shows normal liver function, but he has a history of moderate asthma, for which he uses an inhaler intermittently. Which inhalational agent is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent in patients with reactive airway disease (asthma) because it:

 

  • Has bronchodilator properties, reducing the risk of bronchospasm.
  • Is non-pungent and less irritating to the airways, making induction smooth.
  • Has rapid onset and recovery, which is ideal for elective procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Pungent and can irritate the airways, triggering bronchospasm in asthmatic patients; less suitable for induction.

 

Option C. Halothane: Historically used, but hepatotoxicity risk limits its use; slower onset than sevoflurane.

 

Option D. Nitrous oxide: Not irritating, but weak bronchodilator; usually used as an adjunct, not primary agent for asthmatic patients. Nitrous oxide is the least potent inhalational anesthetic

choices.text: Useful in situations where PO2 is low

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is being managed in the ICU. The intensivist decides to implement Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) in his ventilatory support. Which of the following statements about PEEP is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreases intracranial tension (ICT)

 

  • PEEP increases functional residual capacity and recruits alveoli, improving oxygenation in hypoxic patients.
  • However, PEEP can increase intracranial pressure (ICP) by reducing venous return from the brain, particularly in patients with brain injury.
  • It may also reduce renal perfusion and has minimal direct effect on CO₂ elimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Useful in situations where PO2 is low: True. PEEP is indicated for improving oxygenation in hypoxemic patients.

 

Option B. Decreases carbon dioxide : True. can slightly improve CO₂ elimination via improved alveolar recruitment.

 

Option C. Causes impairment in renal function: True. High intrathoracic pressure can reduce cardiac output and renal perfusion.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect pair

 

  1. Etomidate-Does not cause myocardial suppression
  2. Fospropofol-Maximum pain on injection
  3. Ketamine- Neuroprotective
  4. Thipentone-Best for porphyria
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2,3,4

 

2. Fospropofol – Maximum pain on injection:  Incorrect. Fospropofol is a water-soluble prodrug of propofol, and unlike propofol, it does not cause pain on injection.

 

3. Ketamine – Neuroprotective:  Incorrect. Ketamine increases cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressure, so it is not neuroprotective; it’s relatively contraindicated in patients with raised ICP.

 

4. Thiopentone – Best for porphyria: Incorrect. Thiopentone is a porphyrinogenic drug and can precipitate acute porphyria attacks. Etomidate or propofol is safer in porphyric patients.

 

Correct statement:

 

1. Etomidate – Does not cause myocardial suppression: Etomidate is hemodynamically stable and preserves myocardial function, making it ideal for patients with cardiovascular compromise.

questions.text:
Which of the following is included in high-quality CPR?

  1. Compression depth of at least 5 cm

  2. Rotate chest compressor every 3 mins

  3. Avoid excessive ventilation

  4. Compression - ventilation ratio of 30:2

  5. Allow complete recoil

  6. ET co2 <10mm

  7. Intra-arterial DBP >20mm Hg

  8. Breaths 20-30/min
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, 5, 7

 

High-quality CPR requires:

 

1. Compression depth of at least 5 cm: Ensures adequate cardiac output.

 

3. Avoid excessive ventilation: prevents increased intrathoracic pressure, which can reduce venous return.

 

4. Compression-ventilation ratio of 30:2: standard for adult CPR in a single rescuer scenario.

 

5. Allow complete recoil: Allows the heart to refill between compressions.

 

7. Intra-arterial diastolic pressure >20 mmHg: indicates effective perfusion during compressions.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

2. Rotate chest compressor every 3 mins: Incorrect. Usually recommended every 2 mins to prevent rescuer fatigue, not 3 mins.

 

6. ETCO₂ <10 mmHg: Incorrect: Low ETCO₂ (<10 mmHg) indicates poor perfusion; target is ETCO₂ >10–20 mmHg during CPR.

 

8. Breaths 20–30/min: Incorrect:  Excessive ventilation; recommended rate is 10 breaths/min in adults with advanced airway.

questions.text:
Identify the correct pair of doses:

  1. Max dose of lignocaine without adrenaline-300mg

  2. Dantrolene sodium-2.5mg/kg

  3. Intralipid 20% IV-1.5 mL/kg

  4. Epinephrine in cardiac arrest-1mg 1:10000 iv
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Lignocaine (without adrenaline) – 300 mg: Correct. Maximum safe dose for an adult is 3–5 mg/kg without epinephrine; for a 70 kg adult, ~300 mg is appropriate.

 

Statement 2. Dantrolene sodium – 2.5 mg/kg: Correct. Initial dose for malignant hyperthermia treatment. May repeat until crisis resolves (max cumulative ~10 mg/kg).

 

Statement 3. Intralipid 20% IV – 1.5 mL/kg: Correct. Initial bolus for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). Followed by infusion if needed.

 

Statement 4. Epinephrine in cardiac arrest – 1 mg 1:10,000 IV: Correct. Standard adult dose every 3–5 min during CPR.

questions.text: What is the appropriate size for ET tube for child aged 8?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6mm

 

ET tube size in children can be estimated using the age-based formula (uncuffed tube):

 

  • Internal diameter (mm)=[4/Age in years]​+4

 

Here, for a 8yr child, 8/4+4=6mm

 

  • This size ensures adequate ventilation while minimizing the risk of airway trauma.
  • Cuffed tubes may require 0.5 mm smaller size compared to uncuffed tubes.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about muscle relaxants:

  1. Gallamine and pancuronium have vagolytic activity

  2. Shortest acting approved NDMR is Gantacurium

  3. MR that may cause hypotension and flushing after injection: Tubocurarine

  4. Rocuronium and vecuronium can be reversed by use of Suggamadex
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Gallamine and pancuronium have vagolytic activity: True. Both can increase heart rate by blocking vagal tone.

 

Statement 3. MR that may cause hypotension and flushing after injection: Tubocurarine:  True. Tubocurarine causes histamine release, leading to hypotension and flushing.

 

Statement 4. Rocuronium and vecuronium can be reversed by use of Sugammadex: True. Sugammadex encapsulates aminosteroid NDMRs like rocuronium and vecuronium for rapid reversal.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Shortest acting approved NDMR is Gantacurium:  False. Gantacurium is ultra-short acting but not yet widely approved globally; atracurium or mivacurium are conventionally considered shortest-acting approved NDMRs.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

  1. Lowest MAC=Highest potency

  2. Min MAC-N2o, Max MAC-Methoxyflurane

  3. Blood gas partition coefficient (BGC)=Lipid solubility-Speed of induction

  4. Lowest BGC-Xenon, Highest BGC-Methoxyflurane
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

Statement 1. Lowest MAC = Highest potency: True. MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration) is inversely related to potency; the lower the MAC, the more potent the anesthetic.

 

Statement 4. Lowest BGC – Xenon, Highest BGC – Methoxyflurane: True. Xenon has very low blood solubility → rapid induction and recovery, Methoxyflurane has high BGC → slow induction/recovery. 

 

  • Blood-Gas Partition Coefficient (BGC) is the ratio of anesthetic concentration in blood to that in alveolar gas at equilibrium
  • Low BGC = anesthetic is less soluble in blood, equilibrates quickly → fast onset and offset
  • High BGC = anesthetic is more soluble in blood, equilibrates slowly → slow onset and offset

 

Incorrect Options:

 

  • 2. Min MAC – N₂O, Max MAC – Methoxyflurane: False. Methoxyflurane has low MAC (high potency), while N₂O has high MAC (low potency). This statement is reversed.
  • 3. Blood-gas partition coefficient (BGC) = Lipid solubility – Speed of induction: False. BGC reflects solubility in blood, not directly lipid solubility; lower BGC = faster induction.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding sodalime?

 

  1. 100 g of sodalime can absorb 23 liters of CO2
  2. Amsorb is preferred for Sevoflurane and Desflurane over sodalime 
  3. The major constituent of sodalime is Ca (OH)2
  4. Water content of sodalime is 5%
  5. Can form a neurotoxic compound with Trilene
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Statement 1. 100 g of soda lime can absorb 23 liters of CO₂: True. this is an approximate value for fresh soda lime capacity.

 

Statement 2. Amsorb is preferred for Sevoflurane and Desflurane over soda lime: True. standard soda lime can react with sevoflurane/desflurane to produce toxic compounds (Compound A); Amsorb avoids this.

 

Statement 3. Major constituent of soda lime is Ca(OH)₂: True. calcium hydroxide is the main active component for CO₂ absorption.

 

Statement 5. Can form a neurotoxic compound with Trilene: True – soda lime can react with trichloroethylene (Trilene) producing potentially neurotoxic byproducts.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Water content of soda lime is 5%: False. actual water content is 13–20%, which is required for efficient CO₂ absorption.

questions.text: You are planning to administer spinal anesthesia to a young female. Which of the following needles would be the most suitable for reducing the risk of a post-dural puncture headache?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25G Whitacre

 

  • Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is caused by CSF leak through the dural puncture site.
  • Needle characteristics that reduce PDPH:
    • Smaller gauge → less tissue trauma → smaller dural hole → less CSF leak.
    • Pencil-point (non-cutting) tip → separates rather than cuts dural fibers, promoting faster closure.
  • 25G Whitacre is a small, pencil-point needle, which minimizes PDPH risk compared to cutting needles (Quincke) or larger gauges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 22G Quincke: Larger cutting needle → higher PDPH risk.

 

Option B. 22G Whitacre: Pencil-point, but larger gauge → moderate PDPH risk.

 

Option C. 25G Quincke: Small gauge reduces risk, but the cutting tip still increases PDPH chance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For young adults, especially females, use small-gauge pencil-point needles, so as to reduce the chance of PDPH.

questions.text: Following tube adds additional airway resistance. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diameter of the tube

 

The endotracheal tube shown adds airway resistance primarily due to its diameter. According to Poiseuille’s law, airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius (or diameter). Thus, a narrower diameter increases resistance much more than changes in length, circumference, or curvature.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents for an elective hernia repair. The patient has a forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) of 60% predicted and requires supplemental oxygen on activity. Under what ASA-PS classification would you place him?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ASA 3

 

This patient has severe COPD with functional limitation, so ASA 3 is appropriate. Because, ASA 3: Severe systemic disease, with functional limitation (e.g., FEV1 60%, needs O₂ on activity).

choices.text: Feel for pulse and assess the breathing

questions.text: A 2 years old child was playing with marbles and suddenly went limp and became unresponsive. Mother of the child was beside and saw him collapse. What is the first step to be done my mother in the situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Call emergency medical services

 

  • In a sudden unresponsive child, the first priority is to activate the emergency response system. Immediate EMS call ensures:
  • Rapid arrival of trained personnel
  • Access to advanced airway and resuscitation equipment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Feel for pulse and assess the breathing: While pulse and breathing check is important, calling EMS first (or simultaneously if another adult is present) is recommended by Pediatric Basic Life Support (BLS) guidelines for witnessed collapse.

 

Options C and D Back thrusts and Heimlich maneuver: Back thrusts or Heimlich maneuver are used for choking when the child is conscious and actively choking, not for sudden unresponsiveness.

questions.text:
Arrange following parts of Anesthesia machine according to increasing pressure (from low to high):

 

1. Vaporizer mounting devices

2. Hanger yoke assembly

3. Flow meter assembly

4. Pipelines
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-3-4-2

 

  • Anesthesia machine pressure zones:
  1. Low-pressure system: Includes vaporizer mounting devices and flowmeters; pressures typically < 15 psi.
  2. Intermediate-pressure system: Includes pipelines from central supply: ~50 psi.
  3. High-pressure system: Includes hanger yoke assembly and cylinders: 45–2200 psi depending on cylinder size.
  • Arranging the given parts from lowest to highest pressure:
  1. Vaporizer mounting devices (low)
  2. Flow meter assembly (low)
  3. Pipelines (intermediate)
  4. Hanger yoke assembly (high)

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications of neuraxial blockade except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spinal deformity

 

Spinal deformity (e.g., scoliosis, mild kyphosis) is not an absolute contraindication, though it may make technical placement difficult. Experienced anaesthesiologists can often perform the block safely using landmarks or ultrasound guidance. Thus its an example of Relative Contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Absolute contraindications of neuraxial blockade include:

 

Option B. Patient refusal: Patient autonomy is paramount.

 

Option C. Local infection at puncture site: risk of introducing infection into CNS.

 

Option D. Papilledema: Increased intracranial pressure / Papilledema – risk of brain herniation.

 

List of Contra-indications for Neuraxial Blockade:-

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements: 

 

1. Best site for measuring the core temperature intra-operatively is lower 1/3 of esophagus 

2. Duration of action of proparacaine is 15-20 minutes

 

3. T10 level anesthesia is adequate for LSCS

4. Sch can cause hyperkalemia, tachycardia, raised ICP and raised intra-gastric pressure
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

Statement 1. Lower 1/3 of esophagus for core temperature: True. This site reflects central blood temperature and is considered accurate intra-operatively.

 

Statement 2. Proparacaine duration:  True. Topical proparacaine lasts ~15–20 minutes, commonly used in ophthalmic procedures.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. T10 anesthesia for LSCS:  False. Caesarean section requires at least T4 level block for adequate anesthesia.

 

Statement 4. Succinylcholine adverse effects:  False. effects include hyperkalemia, BRADYcardia[not Tachycardia], increased ICP, and increased intragastric pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not weaning mode of ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CMV

 

  • CMV (Continuous Mandatory Ventilation):
    • CMV delivers fully controlled breaths at a set tidal volume and rate, regardless of whether the patient initiates spontaneous breaths.
    • Because the ventilator completely takes over breathing, the patient’s respiratory muscles do not get used, which can lead to muscle atrophy and delayed weaning.
    • Primary use: CMV is typically used for patients who are apneic, heavily sedated, or during anesthesia, where spontaneous breathing is either absent or undesirable
    • Not suitable for weaning: Since the patient is not required to breathe spontaneously, CMV cannot gradually transition a patient to independent breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SIMV (Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation): Used for weaning; allows patient-initiated breaths between mandatory ventilator breaths.

 

Option C. PSV (Pressure Support Ventilation): Weaning mode; patient controls breathing while the ventilator provides pressure support.

 

Option D. CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure): Weaning mode; spontaneous breathing with positive pressure to maintain alveolar recruitment.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In line manual stabilization

 

The maneuver being performed is in-line manual stabilization of the cervical spine. This is used in trauma cases to prevent any movement of the head and neck, minimizing the risk of spinal cord injury until definitive immobilization (like a cervical collar) is applied.

 

  • Both hands support the patient’s head and neck in a neutral position.
  • There’s no attempt to extend, flex, tilt, or rotate the neck.
  • This technique is crucial in suspected cervical spine injuries during transfers, airway management, or evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head tilt, chin lift:

 

  • The most common basic airway opening technique for unconscious patients without suspected cervical spine injury.
  • The head is tilted backward and the chin lifted upward to open the airway by moving the tongue away from the posterior pharynx.

 

Option B. Jaw thrust:

 

  • Airway maneuver often used when cervical spine injury is suspected.
  • The lower jaw is pushed upward without moving the cervical spine to open the airway.

 

 

Option C. Head extension:

 

  • This is simply moving the head backward to extend the neck.
  • It helps open the airway but can harm patients with cervical spine injury.

choices.text: Duration can be prolonged using an inlaying catheter

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of epidural over spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duration can be prolonged using an inlaying catheter

 

  • Epidural anaesthesia:
    • Involves injection of local anaesthetic into the epidural space outside the dura.
    • A catheter can be inserted, allowing continuous or repeated dosing, so anaesthesia duration can be extended as needed.
  • Spinal anaesthesia:
    • Single-shot injection into the subarachnoid space; limited duration and cannot be prolonged without another puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Less dose of drug required: False. spinal anaesthesia typically requires less drug due to direct intrathecal injection.

 

Option C. Easier technique: False. epidural is technically more difficult than spinal.

 

Option D. Less traumatic needle: False. spinal needles are usually smaller and less traumatic; epidural needles are larger and more invasive.

choices.text: Targeted temperature management at 32 -36° C if patient is awake
Emergent cardiac intervention if STEMI present

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about management of Post-CPR Return of spontaneous circulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Targeted temperature management at 32 -36° C if patient is awake

 

Targeted Temperature Management (TTM):

 

  • Definition: Controlled reduction of a patient’s core body temperature to 32–36°C after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) following cardiac arrest.
  • Primary Goal: To minimize neurological injury caused by ischemia-reperfusion and reduce brain edema.
  • Indications:
    • Comatose patients after ROSC (i.e., not following commands).
    • Helps improve survival and neurological outcomes.
  • Contraindications / Not indicated:
    • Patients who are awake, alert, and following commands do not require TTM, as it offers no added benefit and may increase complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MAP > 65 mmHg: Ensures adequate perfusion to vital organs.

 

Option C. SpO₂ 92–98%:  Avoids hypoxia and hyperoxia.

 

Option D. Emergent cardiac intervention if STEMI present: PCI or reperfusion is indicated.

choices.text: Provide oxygen via nasal cannula and monitor

questions.text: A 34-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his friends after being found unconscious. His friends report that he had been using heroin earlier in the day. On examination, the patient is unresponsive, his respiratory rate is 6 breaths per minute, pupils are pinpoint, and his oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer intravenous naloxone

 

  • The patient presents with symptoms of opioid overdose, characterized by unresponsiveness, respiratory depression (respiratory rate of 6 breaths/min), pinpoint pupils, and low oxygen saturation (85%). 
  • The most appropriate immediate management is the administration of naloxone, an opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation: While intubation may be required in severe cases where naloxone is ineffective, it is not the initial management. Naloxone should be administered first, as it can rapidly improve respiratory effort and prevent the need for intubation.

 

 Option C. Start intravenous fluids and observe: IV fluids do not address the respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose and are not the primary treatment in this case.

 

Option D. Provide oxygen via nasal cannula and monitor: While supplemental oxygen is important to correct hypoxemia, it does not address the underlying cause (opioid-induced respiratory depression). Naloxone remains the priority intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The opioids are lethal in overdose.

 

 

The drug of choice for treatment of opioid overdose is i.v. naloxone (short-acting opioid antagonist).

questions.text: Which color of Venturi device will you use to administer a 40% concentration of oxygen to the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Red 

 

  • Venturi masks deliver precise fixed concentrations of oxygen using different color-coded adapters.
  •  Mechanism: The Venturi adapter entrains room air in a controlled ratio to oxygen flow, allowing accurate FiO₂ delivery, especially useful in COPD patients.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman who is on SSRI for major depression for 6 months underwent hernia surgery. Post-operatively the nurse administered an analgesic for the pain. After some time, the patient developed fever, rigidity, restlessness, and delirium. Clonus is demonstrated on examination. Which of the following is unlikely to have caused her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Buprenorphine 

 

  • The patient shows classic signs of serotonin syndrome:
    • Mental status changes: delirium, restlessness
    • Autonomic dysfunction: fever
    • Neuromuscular abnormalities: rigidity, clonus
  • Serotonin syndrome can occur when drugs that increase serotonergic activity are given to patients on SSRIs.
  • Buprenorphine: Partial μ-opioid agonist and κ-opioid antagonist with minimal serotonergic activity; therefore, unlikely to cause serotonin syndrome. Clinical relevance: Safe for analgesia in patients on SSRIs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meperidine: Mechanism Strong serotonin reuptake inhibitor in addition to μ-opioid agonism. Clinical significance: Can precipitate serotonin syndrome in patients on SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, or other serotonergic drugs.

 

Option C. Tramadol: Mechanism μ-opioid agonist plus inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake. Clinical significance: Common trigger for serotonin syndrome in patients on SSRIs.

 

Option D. Fentanyl: Mechanism: Potent μ-opioid agonist, minor serotonergic activity reported. Clinical significance: Associated with serotonin syndrome; less likely than meperidine or tramadol.

questions.text: A 3-minute-old newborn is being resuscitated due to signs of respiratory distress. Where should the clinical team place the pulse oximeter to measure oxygen saturation in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right upper limb

 

  • In newborn resuscitation, pre-ductal SpO₂ is preferred because it reflects oxygenation before blood mixes through the ductus arteriosus.
  • Right upper limb (typically right hand) is considered pre-ductal, while lower limbs reflect post-ductal oxygen saturation.
  • Importance:
    • Pre-ductal saturation guides initial oxygen therapy in newborns.
    • Post-ductal readings may be lower due to right-to-left shunting across the ductus arteriosus, giving underestimation of arterial oxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left upper limb: Can be pre-ductal, but right upper limb is standard for consistency.

 

Option B. Left lower limb: Post-ductal; may underestimate true systemic oxygenation.

 

Option D. Right lower limb: Post-ductal; less reliable for initial resuscitation guidance.
